text:
KIMBERLY CUMMINGS: I
would love to discuss

what it would look like to
increase my salary based

upon the results
and impact that I've
contributed this past year.

I was looking for an increase
of $10,000 to $15,000.

Then I'd pause, and I'd see
what they were going to say.

CHRISTINE LIU: I have
never before in my life
asked for a raise.

I know it seems shocking,
but I don't know,

there's just like
this weird stigma.

It's really difficult
to talk about money.

I don't know if it's like
cultural or generational,

or just looking back and
thinking about the earlier

parts of my career,
I probably was
underpaid a lot of the time.
And that's not OK.

This is a really
important issue.

And I don't want to
repeat the same mistakes.

And if you're in
the same position,

I don't want you to go
through that either.

Right now, we are
going to figure out

how to ask for a raise
and make sure you're not
leaving any money on the table.

So stick around if you want to
see me figure out these tips
step by step.

I know you all have been asking
for this episode since day one.
So let's get that money.
[MUSIC PLAYING]

Before we start, a brief
word from our sponsor.

We all want better ways to work,
Confluence, the leading team

collaboration, software keeps
your whole company in sync.

Confluence is one place where
you can create, collaborate,

and share work so you can
spend less time meeting
and more time doing.

Get it free today at
atlassian.com/meetless.

KIMBERLY CUMMINGS: This isn't
a conversation where you go in
and wing it.

And when you go in
and wing it, I've

seen happen so many
times where people get

knocked down really fast,
or they say the wrong thing.

And it's hard to
pick it back up.

CHRISTINE LIU: That's
Kimberly B. Cummings.

She's a career coach
consultant and author.

She helps women and people of
color navigate the workplace,

make more money, and
become industry leaders.

Is there anything that
is important to know

about negotiating salary right
now in 2021 as the world turns?

KIMBERLY CUMMINGS:
It's important to know

that the work is still the
work, even though we're virtual.

I feel that so many
places are trying
to say things differently.

Oh, well, because we're
virtual, what is your rate,

or because we're virtual,
let's do it this way.
The work is still the work.

Don't let anyone talk you out
of negotiating what you know you
deserve because it's virtual.

There are so many folks who work
10 times harder being virtual
than they ever did in person.

CHRISTINE LIU:
Although, you might

be tempted to ask your
boss right now for a raise,
just pause for a second.

The first thing you want to do
is get some key information.

KIMBERLY CUMMINGS:
Schedule what I

like to call career
conversation where

you can speak about your
development, your contribution,

where your career
is going and ask,

based upon the work
that I've been doing,

I'd love to discuss what it
would look like to get a raise.

Ask your boss, what
would it look like when
I've achieved this too?

Be very specific
so you can really

create an actionable
plan to achieve it.

CHRISTINE LIU: Now we're going
to get into the tactical stuff,
negotiation and the ask.
First step, do your research.

KIMBERLY CUMMINGS:
Look at how much

you're being paid in comparison
to other similar organizations

to see what is the rate
you should be looking for.
Are you under?
Are you over?

What's happening
in your industry?

I recommend sites like
Glassdoor, Payscale, LinkedIn,
everything.

CHRISTINE LIU: Aside from online
research, what can really help

is getting real data
from real people.

And that means talking to
others and if you trust them,
asking them, what they make.

KIMBERLY CUMMINGS: If you do
have a close relationship,

I do recommend
asking, hey, can we

have the salary conversation,
like real number conversation.

CHRISTINE LIU: What's
really important

is understanding why a
raise needs to happen.
What are your contributions?
How have you made an impact?

Why should the company
increase its investment in you?

KIMBERLY CUMMINGS:
Many times employees

will talk about I want to
raise, because I deserve it.
I've done so much here.
I need this.
I need this.

However, when we're
thinking about it

from a business
perspective, you're

getting paid more, because
you are doing more.
Your contribution is higher.

Your value in the
workplace is higher.

These are value-based
conversations,

not just I deserve
or I feel like I
don't have conversations.

CHRISTINE LIU: It's
one thing for you

to make a case for yourself,
but it's so helpful if others
can help you do that too.
What does that mean?

It means building your personal
brand inside the company.

This is like my favorite
tip from Kimberly.

If someone at work
complements you on a project,

or says thank you, or
whatever, at that moment,

just ask that person, hey,
that's so great to hear.

Actually, if you
don't mind, can you

drop a line to my boss
with the same message
that you shared with me?
It would mean a lot.
Thanks so much.

KIMBERLY CUMMINGS:
Something quick and easy.

And many times that email
just helps reinforce the value
that you're bringing.

CHRISTINE LIU: Now's
the time that you

sit down with your boss
and lay everything out.

And even if you are on friendly
terms with your manager,

you want to come into
this conversation
with a bit of seriousness.
So I have the research.
I'm going into the conversation.

What advice would you have
for like actually expressing

the number, or the
range, or the percentage?
Like how do I give that numeral?
KIMBERLY CUMMINGS: Yes.

So you definitely want
to express a range.

So let's say you're currently
getting paid $55,000 a year

and you really want to
be at $65,000 a year.

I would quote a range of
$65,000 a year to $75,000 a year

when you're having
this conversation

with the number you
really want at the lowest
part of the range.

CHRISTINE LIU:
Because that's like

if they do go with the low, then
you've already hit your goal.
KIMBERLY CUMMINGS: Exactly.

CHRISTINE LIU: If
you get nervous,

just remember restraint
is your friend.
Just stop talking.

KIMBERLY CUMMINGS: They'll
start saying things like,

well, I really want to
raise, because I think

I've done a lot of
work here, and then I
saw someone else get a raise.

Ask the question,
and then zip it.

CHRISTINE LIU: I want to
leave this conversation

with a clear idea of next
steps and timeline when are you
going to hear back from them.
So the ball's in their court.
You wait a little bit.

If you haven't heard back, just
bring it up again, nudge them.
Don't be afraid to be proactive.

What do you do if they come
back with not what you expected,

or a lowball, or something
that isn't what you ask for?

KIMBERLY CUMMINGS: I always want
to validate that it stinks when

you've done all you can do and
they come back with, let's say,

a 1 to 5 k difference in
what you're currently making,

which we know is most likely
going to get eaten up by taxes.

So when they come back with
that number, of course,

reiterating I was looking for an
increase of $10,000 to $15,000.
Is there any wiggle room here?

If they say, no, then I
would follow up and say,

of course, well, you're
going to take the money,

but what do they need to see
from you in order to increase?

CHRISTINE LIU: There's only
so much you can control.

So if your request for a
raise isn't going as expected,

it might be time
to get creative.

KIMBERLY CUMMINGS:
This might also

be the time where you may
have to have the conversation,

do you actually need
a raise, or do you
need a promotional opportunity?

CHRISTINE LIU: Asking
for a raise is not easy.

And it can get emotionally and
psychologically complicated
real fast.

KIMBERLY CUMMINGS: This
is a tough conversation
that a lot of people don't have.
You have to practice.
CHRISTINE LIU: All right.
So currently I'm making $45,000.

And I am looking to raise my
salary to $55,000 to $60,000.
I don't know.
I'm getting sweaty.

I feel like the more
that I say it out

loud, the emotional and
psychological trappings

of saying a number out loud
diminish, $80,000, $40,000,

I can say that, but can
I say from $45 to $55?

I don't know why
that's much harder.
OK.
So I have a number.

And I'm ready to give
my pitch for a raise.

For the purposes
of the video, I'm

actually going to go back to
Kimberly and deliver my spiel

and see what she
says, what she thinks,

and give real
critique out of it.

Before we see me
put it all together,

here's a message from
our sponsor Confluence.
JASON FAN: Hi.

I'm Jason Fan from
Confluence with five tips

to make your hybrid
meetings more effective.

First, ask yourself, do
we really need to meet?

Meeting fatigue is real, but the
right team collaboration tool,

like Confluences
Open Workspace makes

information transparent
and readily available
to all team members.

You can keep your teams in
sync and cut down on meetings.

Second, use a hybrid media tool
to give everyone equal access

without any
permission roadblocks

and to encourage more team
involvement, more knowledge

sharing, and more
meaningful collaboration.

Next, set an agenda with
contributions from the team.

The best hybrid meetings
are collaborative.

Use status updates, to-do list,
decision-making frameworks,

and other templates so
that everyone can weigh in.

You'll be surprised at how
much shorter your meetings will

be when issues are
dispatched in events.
Fourth, invite only key people.

Inviting too many people can
make decision-making harder

and can suppress participation
for a productive conversation.

Try to keep your team meetings
to 10 essential stakeholders
or fewer.

Last, after the meeting,
share your notes.

Hybrid meetings
stay useful when you

post-meeting notes, especially
decisions and action items

and make them readily
available to team members.

Organize them with labels or
in shared folders and spaces

so that your team can easily
delve into the information
they need.

We use Confluences
open workspace

to keep our team
meetings organized.

Spend less time meeting
and more time doing.

Get Confluence free today
at atlassian.com/meetless.

KIMBERLY CUMMINGS:
You look fabulous.
CHRISTINE LIU: Thank you.

I believe I brought a
lot of impact and results
to the company this past year.
Just some highlights.

So one, in our initiative
for audience growth,

I managed to write and innovate
on our neighborhood guides.

Also, I gave some suggestions
to the workflow and structure.

And so actually
now a year later,

we are spending 20%
of our time less--

we're spending 20% less
of our time in meetings.

So I think that's a really
big boon to our productivity.

So based on the results and
impact of those highlights,

my salary ask is
$55,000 to $60,000.
KIMBERLY CUMMINGS: OK.
OK.

I appreciate you sharing
that with me today.

I think I'm going to take
that back to our team

and see what we're
able to do here.
CHRISTINE LIU: Great.

So thank you so much
for the consideration.

I'll just send a recap of what
we talked about in a follow up

email, but I really appreciate
you taking this time.

And also, do you have
an estimate of when
I might be able to hear back?

KIMBERLY CUMMINGS: So I have
a leadership team meeting
next week.

I hope I'll be able to get
back to you in two weeks.
CHRISTINE LIU: I tried my best.

I did practice, but I would love
to hear from your point of view
how strange where I can improve.

I know it's a little robotic
to me, but at the same time,

I know I would be flailing
left and right if I
didn't have a bit of structure.

KIMBERLY CUMMINGS: No, I don't
think you were flailing at all.

One of the things I will say is
that try to remove words like I

actually from your vocabulary
when you're doing that.

It acts like, well, I'm
so shocked like I actually
was able to do this.
No, you did it.
You did it, and it was amazing.

CHRISTINE LIU:
Talking with Kimberly,

it was fairly straightforward,
but I can only

imagine there are
certain conversations

and certain managers where
things can escalate really
quickly.

KIMBERLY CUMMINGS: Don't
get discouraged at all,

even if the manager
were to say, hey,

let's talk about that in
three months at the midyear.

Say, well, I'd love to make sure
that I'm on track to receive
a promotion.

Would you be able to share
what you'd need to see?

CHRISTINE LIU: As
I mentioned before,

I had never asked for a
raise before in my career.

And now knowing what
I know, I definitely

feel like I have a
lot more confidence.

The cat's out of the bag,
ball's in their court,

and then you just have the
sense of accomplishment.

And whatever
happens, it happens,
but you did what you could.

And I think that's
really powerful.

If you're still
watching, one, thank you.

But two, I'm really
curious, like
what do you want me to explore?

Like what problems
do you have at work?
I'd love to solve them.

KIMBERLY CUMMINGS:
Please leave a comment.
I'd love to hear your thoughts.

And if you have any other
ideas, throw them my way.
All right.
Peace out.
